--- title: Gluteus Maximus Muscle --- # Overview The gluteus maxijmus is a primary extensor and external rotator of the hip @neumannKinesiologyMusculoskeletalSystem2017. The gluteus maximus is a secondary hip abductor @neumannKinesiologyMusculoskeletalSystem2017 The gluteus maximus also plays an important role in stabilization of the SIJ and lumbar spine via its ligamentous and fascial originations @neumannKinesiologyMusculoskeletalSystem2017 ::: {#tbl-oian .cell message='false' execution_count=1} ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display} ```{=html}

``` ::: ::: # Origin {#origin} - Sacrum (dorsal surface, lateral part) @gilroyAtlasAnatomy2020 - Ilium (gluteal surface, posterior part) @gilroyAtlasAnatomy2020 - Thoracolumbar fascia @gilroyAtlasAnatomy2020 - [Sacrotuberous lig.]({{< var ref-sacrotuberous-ligament.path >}}) @gilroyAtlasAnatomy2020 # Insertion {#insertion} - **Upper fibers**: iliotibial tract @gilroyAtlasAnatomy2020 - **Lower fibers**: gluteal tuberosity @gilroyAtlasAnatomy2020 # Innervation {#innervation} The gluteus maximus muscle is innervated by nerve roots [L5]({{< var ref-nerve-root.l5 >}}), [S1]({{< var ref-nerve-root.s1 >}}), [S2]({{< var ref-nerve-root.s2 >}}) via the [Inferior gluteal nerve]({{< var ref-inferior-gluteal-nerve.path >}}) @gilroyAtlasAnatomy2020 # Action {#action} - Entire muscle: extends and externally rotates the hip in sagittal and coronal planes @gilroyAtlasAnatomy2020 - Upper fibers: Hip abduction @gilroyAtlasAnatomy2020 - Lower fibers: Hip adduction @gilroyAtlasAnatomy2020 At ≥60° hip flexion, the *upper fibers* of the gluteus maximus switch and produce an *internal rotation* torque @neumannKinesiologyMusculoskeletalSystem2017. ::: {.callout-note} Since the glute max can only abduct with its *highest* fibers, the majority of the muscle's force in the frontal plane is into adduction @jonesProjectFoundations2025. ::: # Practical function ROM and intensity will modulate glute max involvement @jonesProjectFoundations2025. Hip extension during walking recruits more hamstring activation and miniscule glute max @jonesProjectFoundations2025. Increasing the activity intensity to running or jumping will cause a much greater Glute max recruitment @jonesProjectFoundations2025. Likewise, increase the amount of hip flexion required, such as running up a steep slope will also increase glute max recruitment @jonesProjectFoundations2025. # Biomechanics The moment arm of the gluteus maximus decreases as the hip moves into flexion @neumannKinesiologyMusculoskeletalSystem2017. The more hip flexion decreases the moment arm of the gluteus maximus and therefore results in less torque @neumannKinesiologyMusculoskeletalSystem2017. # Length test {#length-test} # Manual Muscle Test {#mmt} # Exercises A wedge forcing the foot into hyper-dorsiflexion will cause the client to prevent excessive anterior knee translation and force more hip hinge, which will activate the glutes. - Single leg bridge (with 90° knee flexion and pushing through the hindfoot) - Wall triple extension - Bridge (toes up) - S/L Hip abduction to high knee
